title: 109_s1077
content: RENEWABLE LIQUID FUELS EXCISE TAX CREDIT. A new section, SEC. 6426A, is added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide a credit for renewable liquid fuels. The renewable liquid mixture credit allows a tax credit against the tax imposed by section 4081 for the product of the applicable amount and the number of gallons of renewable liquid used in producing a renewable liquid mixture for sale or business use. The applicable amount is $1.00, and a renewable liquid mixture is defined as a mixture of renewable liquid and taxable fuel sold for use as a fuel or feedstock. The renewable liquid mixture credit allows a tax credit for the product of the applicable amount and gallons of renewable liquid used in producing a mixture for sale or business use. Renewable liquid is derived from waste streams like agricultural byproducts, aquaculture products, food processing plant byproducts, and municipal waste. The curr_chunk provides definitions for terms related to renewable liquid fuel tax credits, including taxable fuel, feedstock, and additional definitions. No credit is allowed unless the taxpayer obtains certification for renewable liquid fuel. Taxpayer must obtain certification from the producer of renewable liquid fuel to claim tax credits. If the renewable liquid is separated from a mixture or used for purposes other than fuel, a tax is imposed on the person equal to the applicable amount multiplied by the number of gallons of renewable liquid. The section discusses the registration requirement for producers or importers of renewable liquid fuel and the termination of the tax provision after December 31, 2010. Coordination with the exemption from excise tax is also mentioned. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new subsection regarding payments for renewable liquid used to produce a mixture. This provision applies to mixtures described in section 6426A, with the Secretary paying an amount equal to the renewable liquid mixture credit. However, no payment is made if a credit is already allowed under section 6426A. This subsection does not apply to renewable liquid fuel mixtures sold or used after December 31, 2010. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new subsection for payments related to renewable liquid used in mixtures. The amendment excludes renewable liquid fuel mixtures sold or used after December 31, 2010. Additionally, there are conforming and clerical amendments made to sections 9503(b)(1) and the table of sections for subchapter B of chapter 65. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section for a credit related to renewable liquid fuels used as fuel, effective after December 31, 2005. The new section of the Internal Revenue Code provides a renewable liquid credit for the production of renewable liquid fuel mixtures. The credit is based on the amount of renewable liquid fuel used in the mixture, with a set amount per gallon. The new section of the Internal Revenue Code provides a renewable liquid credit for the production of renewable liquid fuel mixtures, based on the sale or use of renewable liquid in a trade or business for fuel or feedstock purposes. The renewable liquid credit allows taxpayers to receive $1.00 for each gallon of renewable liquid used as fuel or sold at retail for vehicle use, excluding sales in a retail sale. The taxpayer must obtain certification from the producer or importer of renewable liquid fuel to claim the credit. The credit amount is reduced if other benefits apply. "Renewable liquid" refers to liquid hydrocarbons derived from waste and byproduct streams. The text discusses the use of renewable liquid fuels derived from waste streams and byproducts to claim a tax credit. If the renewable liquid is separated from a mixture or used for purposes other than fuel, a tax is imposed on the person responsible. The text imposes a tax on individuals who mix or use renewable liquid fuels for purposes other than fuel, based on the applicable rate and the number of gallons used. The text imposes penalties for taxes on renewable liquid fuels, with rules for estates and trusts, and a termination date of December 31, 2010. Additionally, a renewable liquid credit is included as part of the general business credit. The text introduces a renewable liquid credit under section 40B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A, inserting the new item after section 40A. The amendments made by section 40B apply to fuel produced and sold after December 31, 2005.
